items.title: Wheels, Old and New
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A wagon wheel, meant to become a chandelier in a second life.

items.title: A Hidden Warrior in the Park
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A new acquaintance finds a bronze statue of an American Indian in a trash can in Carl Schurz Park.

items.title: Walking Like a New Yorker
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: In Los Angeles, a New Yorker is identified by his quick step.

items.title: A Passionate Embrace at the Bus Stop
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poem about two older people behaving with affection while waiting for a bus to arrive.

items.title: For New York, From Paris, With Love
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: After several years in the City of Light, a returning New Yorker tells why she prefers the City That Never Sleeps.

items.title: New York City Is Set to Adopt New Approach on Policing Minor Offenses
items.abstract: The measures would affect low-level offenses such as littering, public urination and public consumption of alcohol, in some cases removing them from the criminal justice system.

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Makes New York City’s Fiscal Case to a Wary Legislature
items.abstract: The mayor asked for state funding for city public housing and homelessness prevention programs, while some lawmakers argued that the city should receive less help from Albany.

items.title: China Moves to Halt ‘Weird’ Architecture
items.abstract: A directive issued by the State Council and the Communist Party’s Central Committee says buildings should be “pleasing to the eye.’’

items.title: Co-op City for Affordability and Open Spaces
items.abstract: Co-op City is mostly open space, with wide lawns and bike paths. But the community’s primary perk is the below-market-rate homes.

items.title: New York City to Ban Discrimination Based on Hair
items.abstract: New guidelines out this week give legal recourse to individuals who have been harassed, punished or fired because of the style of their hair.
keywords: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

items.title: Pope Issues Law, With Penalties, for Vatican City to Address Sexual Abuse
items.abstract: The highly anticipated law is intended to be a model for the Roman Catholic Church worldwide, but critics say it does not go far enough.

items.title: Tenants May Get More Protections in New York City, After Decades of Battles. Here’s Why.
items.abstract: Newly empowered Democrats in Albany have hopes of approving a cadre of bills aimed at tightening rent regulations.

items.title: ‘Although I Tried to Look Away, I Saw Him Gesture Toward Me’
items.abstract: Eavesdropping at dinner, a favor repaid on the M116 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

items.title: San Francisco Bans Facial Recognition Technology
items.abstract: It is the first ban by a major city on the use of facial recognition technology by the police and all other municipal agencies.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: ‘I Asked a Woman on the Platform if She Had Any Tissues’
items.abstract: Helping hands in the subway, a tug of war on the Upper East Side and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

items.title: Sarah Palin, who is unvaccinated, dined outdoors in New York City days after testing positive.
items.abstract: The unvaccinated former Alaska governor returned to Elio’s, the Upper East Side restaurant where she had been seen dining indoors on Saturday despite the city’s requirement that indoor guests show proof of vaccination.

items.title: Where You Still Need to Wear a Mask in New York City
items.abstract: Most mask requirements have been rolled back, including those that apply to public transit. Here’s an overview.

items.title: ‘I Don’t Dare Get the Shot’: Virus Ravages Unvaccinated Older Hong Kongers
items.abstract: Covid has surged through nursing homes in Hong Kong, but older residents are still among the city’s least vaccinated and the most skeptical.
